content.webTitle: This week only in arts: Remember Tomorrow, Del Kathryn Barton and John Armstrong in conversation, and the sonic experience of Mesmerism

fields.headline: This week only: Remember Tomorrow, Del Kathryn Barton and John Armstrong, Mesmerism
fields.bodyText: Del Kathryn Barton and John Armstrong: in conversation Melbourne’s School of Life brings artist Del Kathryn Barton and philosopher John Armstrong together to tackle some of the art world’s most fundamental questions, including how art can play a therapeutic role in friendship, work, love and staying calm. Del Kathryn Barton & John Armstrong in conversation, National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, 19 February Yasukichi Murakami: Through a distant lens Performer Mayu Kanamori tells the poignant story of Yasukichi Murakami, the photographer, entrepreneur and inventor who worked in Broome and Darwin in the early 1900s. Using the stories behind Murakami’s photographs, lost after the outbreak of the Second World War, Kanamori captures something of the history of the Japanese in Australia. Yasukichi Murakami: Through a distant lens, Griffin theatre, Sydney, until 21 February Summersalt festival Melbourne’s Southbank has been revitalised this summer with five weekends of music, dance, theatre, art, interactive installations, street art, storytelling and workshops. Don’t miss the final weekend which features the digital dance Pixel Mountain, canine delight Farnsworth’s Republic for Dogs and urban puppet safari Where the Wild Things Sing. Summersalt festival, Melbourne Arts Precinct, until 21 February Mesmerism summer festival Sonic artist Luke Jaaniste presents two nights of vibrating, trembling, amplified sound experiences for the entire body. Each night he performs his own work on grand piano and multiple vintage keyboards, and is joined by special guests including sound artist Michaela Davies and percussionist Vanessa Tomlinson. Mesmerism summer festival, Judith Wright Centre of Contemporary Arts, Brisbane, from 20 to 21 February Remember Tomorrow The Australian String Quartet presents an evocative program to mark the Anzac centenary and celebrate its 30th anniversary year. The evening includes Haydn’s Emperor quartet, the world premiere of Ross Edwards’ Gallipoli, and Shostakovich’s stirring third string quartet. Remember Tomorrow, Albany Entertainment Centre on 19 February and Government House Ballroom on 20 February, as part of Perth festival
